coredata.dc:description: Thermal experience and thermal exposure are important aspects of thermal adaptation. However, the dynamic effects on thermal adaptation of thermal experiences and thermal history are not well understood. Migrants' long-term thermal adaptation process when transferring from Hot Summer and Cold Winter (HSCW), Hot Summer and Warm Winter (HSWW), and Severe Cold (SC) to Cold regions in China were studied in a longitudinal climate chamber experiment. We conducted repeated tests and systematic evaluations of the physiological and psychological responses of migrants on the time scales of day, week, month, and season. The results show that the difference in thermal exposure level between migrants’ original and current residence needed to drive the development of cold adaptation is greater than that of heat adaptation. The thermal sensitivity and comfortable temperature of the migrants varied and were related to the origin and time of migration. The psychological adaptation dominated the thermal adaptation development in the southern migrants and the physiological adaptation dominated in the northern migrants. The results contribute to understanding the mechanisms of longer-term thermal adaptation and quantifying longer-term indoor thermal experience in future thermal adaptation models.

ce:abstract-sec.ce:simple-para: Thermal experience and thermal exposure are important aspects of thermal adaptation. However, the dynamic effects on thermal adaptation of thermal experiences and thermal history are not well understood. Migrants' long-term thermal adaptation process when transferring from Hot Summer and Cold Winter (HSCW), Hot Summer and Warm Winter (HSWW), and Severe Cold (SC) to Cold regions in China were studied in a longitudinal climate chamber experiment. We conducted repeated tests and systematic evaluations of the physiological and psychological responses of migrants on the time scales of day, week, month, and season. The results show that the difference in thermal exposure level between migrants’ original and current residence needed to drive the development of cold adaptation is greater than that of heat adaptation. The thermal sensitivity and comfortable temperature of the migrants varied and were related to the origin and time of migration. The psychological adaptation dominated the thermal adaptation development in the southern migrants and the physiological adaptation dominated in the northern migrants. The results contribute to understanding the mechanisms of longer-term thermal adaptation and quantifying longer-term indoor thermal experience in future thermal adaptation models.

ce:section.ce:para: Thermal comfort is an important parameter in architectural design, because it affects the well-being, health and performance of occupants. Fanger established the Predicted Mean Vote (PMV) index through steady and well-controlled climate chamber experiments [ 1]. Thermal comfort standards used in building design and operation based on the PMV model are now widely accepted [ 2]. However, many field surveys of naturally ventilated buildings without mechanical cooling show that occupants may feel comfortable in a broader temperature range than predicted by the PMV model. Brager and de Dear therefore suggested an alternative comfort model based on adaptive comfort theory [ 3]. The model can be used to design naturally ventilated or mixed-mode buildings.

Brager and de Dear believed that people's thermal sensation relied on behavioral adjustment, physiological adaptation, and psychological adaptation [ 3]. These three adaptation mechanisms were found to be affected by past thermal experiences and the current exposure levels [ 4]. However, the adaptive mechanisms behind the adaptive comfort model are not yet fully understood. In today's globalized world, human migration between locations in different climate zones is rather common. Therefore, exploring the dynamic effects on thermal adaptation of past thermal experience and current thermal exposure may help to understand better the theory [ 4, 5].

In this paper, thermal experience refers to the thermal environment that people have experienced in their short-term or long-term past [ 6, 7]. The short-term thermal experience refers to the effects of indoor or outdoor thermal exposures over weeks, days, hours, even seconds [ 8–10]. Most studies used climate chamber experiments to quantify the thermal response from minutes [ 11] to several days [ 12–14]. The common conclusion of these studies was that previous short-term thermal experience from a non-neutral environment to a neutral environment might broaden the acceptable temperature range. The long-term thermal experience reflects how people adapt to changes in the climate where they have lived for years. For long-term indoor thermal experience, Wu et al. compared the thermal adaptation in winter of two groups of people who had heating available or not to understand the influence of the indoor heating history on the comfort and thermoregulation of residents [ 15]. The results showed that compared with people used to indoor heating, people without heating adapted less physiologically and felt more comfortable under cold exposure at 12 °C. Jowkar et al. studied the long-term thermal adaptation of migrants from three groups with different climate background; warmer, similar, and colder, compared with the UK [ 16]. The study showed that people with warmer thermal experiences had the broadest range of acceptable temperatures when exposed to the indoor operative temperature in the range 18–25 °C, compared with the other thermal experience groups.

Thermal sensation is affected by a combination of both current and historical thermal exposures [ 17]. Long-term thermal stimuli can enhance or weaken the physical and psychological expression shaped by the thermal experience [ 18]. Launay et al. tested the thermoregulation of migrants from temperate climate in extremely hot temperature conditions (47 °C) both before and after a four-week journey in a tropical climate. The results showed that the migrants had a higher sweat rate and lower skin temperature after staying in the tropics than before [ 19]. Although previous studies attempted to explain the association between thermal comfort and thermal experience or thermal exposure, the mechanisms underlying thermal adaptation are not yet fully understood.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Migrants' perspective: adaptation under long-term thermal experience and exposure
ce:section.ce:para: Migrants are obvious objects in studies on thermal adaptation of long-term thermal experience and exposure. Migrants have different long-term climate backgrounds, and their thermal adaptation characteristics will change dynamically with different intensities and durations of thermal exposure. A wide range of climate chamber studies explored the mechanisms of human physiological regulation [ 20], some targeted the Arctic [ 21], and some military expansion [ 22]. Some studies reported that the physiological parameters of migrants from temperate zones, such as metabolic rate and body temperature, were adapted to extreme climate after weeks of migration [ 23]. Wijayanto et al. conducted a series of thermoregulatory studies on migrants from the tropics migrating to Japan [ 24–26]. They found that the nature of inhibition of the perspiration rate of passive heat exposure acquired by migrants in their long-term thermal experience would be attenuated by less than four years' stay in temperate regions.

Nowadays, researchers pay attention to the perceived adaptation level of migrants with different climate backgrounds due to the increasing pursuit of comfort and energy conservation in buildings; the migration concerned in their studies is mostly between different types of temperate climates because human activities are highly concentrated in comfortable climate zones. Some studies often reported the obvious differences in thermal sensation and thermal expectation between migrants and local people after several months or years of migration [ 27, 28]; the results emphasized the importance of thermal experience in determining people's thermal comfort in buildings. Ji et al. [ 29] investigated the thermal preferences of Chinese migrants living in Sydney (Australia) for 1–48 weeks. They found that the preferred temperature and corresponding skin temperature of Chinese immigrants who came to Sydney for more than two weeks increased compared with those within two weeks of migration. In addition, some studies consider that the outdoor climate is the driver of indoor climate design and focus on observing the thermal adaptation process of migrants with different HVAC control methods. Luo et al. investigated the dynamic thermal adaptation of migrants from southern China who had no experience of indoor heating in winter after migrating to northern China where indoor heating is available [ 30–33]. After exposure to an unheated environment for three years, the acceptable temperature range of people with heating experience was widened and their thermal sensitivity decreased. Kalmár et al. investigated the thermal perception of Nigerian and Turkish migrants with air-conditioning experience after 1–2 years of migration to Hungary, where air-conditioned buildings are not common [ 34]. The results showed that the migrants preferred lower indoor temperature after having air-conditioning available during this period.

However, these studies were cross-sectional, and mainly focused on the differences in physiological and psychological adaptation between migrants and local people at a specific migration time. Moreover, most previous studies were conducted in summer and winter with extreme indoor and outdoor temperatures, which is conducive to capturing migrants' thermal adaptation response in high-intensity thermal exposure. However, migrants live in the passage of time; their adaptation to the new environment is affected by their thermal history and includes the accumulation of seasonal adaptation to the new environment. Therefore, tracing the thermal response of migrants at different time scales in the new environment can be helpful to understand the adaptation mechanisms of the longer-term thermal experience and thermal exposure.

Our previous papers [ 35, 36] studied the effects of different thermal experience on migrants' psychological and behavioral adaptation. In this study, we conducted a longitudinal climate chamber experiment to understand better the thermal adaptation of migrants with different indoor and outdoor thermal experiences under long-term, mild thermal exposure.

China spans both temperate and tropical regions and can be subdivided into several climatic zones, as shown in Fig. 1 . The Chinese government divided the south and the north with the Qinling-Huaihe River as the border; the summer in the south is hot and humid; it is relatively cold and dry in the north. The Chinese government has established public heating systems in the north; however, heating systems are rare in the south. This study was conducted in Xi'an, Shaanxi Province, which is located in the cold climate region of China. Xi'an was chosen as the migration destination in order to observe the thermal adaptation characteristics of migrants from different climate regions ( Fig. 1). The experiment was carried out in a climate chamber at Xi'an University of Architecture and Technology. The chamber size is 3.6 × 3.3 × 2.8 m with a 0.5 × 0.8 m window on the east wall ( Fig. 2 ). The chamber is equipped with an air-conditioning system, controlling the air temperature within ±0.1 °C.

Considering that individual differences may affect the thermal sensation of the subjects, this study recruited 20 students as subjects and carried out a follow-up experiment. We recruited migrants in freshman network groups before beginning the new semester. We requested the subjects to complete the experiment within 24 h after arriving in Xi'an. Migrants came from the Hot Summer and Cold Winter (HSCW), Hot Summer and Warm Winter (HSWW), and Severe Cold (SC) areas of China. Before the survey, all migrants lived only in the area of their origin. The indoor climate experienced by the migrants is shown in Fig. 1. The local people in Xi'an served as the control group. Each group consisted of five subjects, and the proportion of males and females was similar. The university dormitories of all subjects in Xi'an were equipped with public heating systems, fans but no air conditioning systems. The subjects are young college students in Xi'an with high school diplomas or bachelor's degrees. None of the subjects had any disease in their main organs and had a healthy body mass index (BMI) with the range of 18.5–24.9. Before each experiment, it was assured that the subjects had had a regular diet and schedule, no excessive exercise and no serious medical history, so as to avoid circadian rhythm, exercise habits, and disease on the experiment. Table 1 shows anthropometric and demographic characteristics of the four groups. We informed the subjects of the purpose and details of the experiment and got their approval before the experiment.

The experiment lasted from September 2016 to July 2018. Twenty repeated experiments were conducted on the first day, fourth day, seventh day, ninth day, 12th day, 15th day, third week, fourth week, third month, fourth month, fifth month, seventh month, eighth month, ninth month, 10th month, 11th month, 13th month, 16th month, 19th month and 22nd month after the migrants arrived at Xi'an. The first day of migration is defined as 24 h after the first arrival in Xi'an. For the Xi'an group, the experiment was carried out once every season. The outdoor temperature and relative humidity during the experiment are shown in Fig. 3 .

During the experiment, the environmental parameters (air temperature, air humidity, air speed, and wall temperature) were continuously measured. The equipment layout is shown in Fig. 2. Skin temperature, core temperature, blood pressure, and heart rate were also measured. Oral temperature represents the core temperature. The oral temperature was measured by placing an electronic thermometer in a sublingual pocket under the tongue for about 2 min [ 42]. Subjects were requested to close their mouth as much as possible to avoid the interference of ambient temperature. Mean arterial blood pressure (MAP) [ 43] is used to represent the combined level of measured systolic (SP) and diastolic (DP) blood pressures, as the following Equation (1) shown.
Equation 1 MAP ≈0.667 × DP + 0.333 × SP

The number and location of measuring points affect the calculation method of the average skin temperature. Liu et al. pointed out that the four-point method has the advantages of high reliability, high sensitivity, and few measuring points [ 44]. Therefore, the skin temperature was measured by the four-point method. The measurement points included the right upper arm, left chest, right thigh front, and right calf front. The average skin temperature calculated by the 4-point method is shown in Equation (2).
Equation 2 T Average skin Temperature = 0.3 × (T Upper right arm + T Left chest) + 0.2 × (T Front of right thigh + T Front of right calf)

Before the experiment, the sensitivity and accuracy of all instruments were checked and calibrated, and the instruments measuring physiological parameters were disinfected. Table 2 lists the measured parameters, equipment, specifications, and recording intervals.

In addition, hardcopies of questionnaires were applied. The seven-point scale was used to evaluate thermal sensation (TSV). The four-point scale was used for thermal comfort vote (TCV). Table 3 lists the criteria for thermal environment assessment.

Seven experimental conditions (33/31/28/26/24/21/18 °C) were created in the climate chamber, including seven thermal sensation levels from hot to cold. Fig. 4 shows the detailed experimental steps. The subjects wore uniform clothing during the experiment, including short-sleeved shirt, shorts, underwear, socks, and sandals. Based on the effective clothing insulation table in ASHRAE-55 [ 45] and Equation (3) [ 46], we calculated that the total clothing insulation is 0.45 clo. Subjects were required to experience seven experimental conditions in every experiment. The order of experimental conditions was random. There are no more than five subjects in each experimental session. In the preparation stage, the subjects needed to change clothes, attach physiological sensors, learn how to operate the experimental instrument and be familiar with the questionnaire. The subjects were asked to stay in the preparation room (26 °C, 50% ± 10%) for 30 min. Then, they entered the climate chamber to fill in the first questionnaire. The time interval for filling in the questionnaire was 5 min. Each condition lasted 40 min. During the experiment, all subjects were asked to sit still, and their metabolic rate was about 1.1met. The actual thermal environment parameters of the climate chamber under experimental conditions are shown in Table 4 .
Equation 3

We analyze the data from the last 10 min of each test case. Principal Coordinate Analysis (PCoA) based on Bray Curtis distance was used to visualize the similarity of thermophysiological responses of the subjects. Because the thermophysiological responses did not follow a normal distribution, permanent multivariate analysis of variance (PERMANOVA) was used to examine the influence of the migration time, origin, and experimental temperature on the thermophysiological responses. The function ENVFIT was used to calculate the correlation between migration time, experimental temperature, and PCoA ordination axes in different migration groups. The functions used in the above analysis are provided by the vegan package in R [ 47]. A Random Forest (RF) algorithm was used to rank the physiological parameters by their importance in distinguishing migration times, origin, and experiment temperatures. In order to describe the non-linear components of the trend, the effects of migration origin, time, and the experimental temperature on subjects’ thermal responses (skin temperature, TSV, and TCV) were fitted by a generalized additive mixture model (GAMM). In addition, generalized estimation equations (GEE) were used to evaluate the thermal response under different migration times and origins followed by a Tukey Post-hoc test. ANOVA was used to determine the significance of the regression relationship. The significance level of all the above tests was set at 0.05. RF algorithm, GEE, and GAMM were performed using the randomForest [ 48], geepack [ 49–51], and mgcv [ 52] packages in R (version 3.6.3) [ 53].

ce:section.ce:section-title: Overall structure analysis of the physiological response
ce:section.ce:para: As shown in Fig. 5 (a), PCoA illustrated the thermophysiological response divergence among the different migration groups. The percentage of variance explained by each PCoA axis is 57.3% and 38.8%, respectively. In a PCoA diagram, objects closer to each other are more similar than objects farther away. We observed an obvious trend of separation between the HSCW and SC groups, whereas the HSWW and the HSCW groups could not be separated. There were significant differences in migration origin, migration time, and experimental temperature (P = 0.001, PERMANOVA). Migration origin (P = 0.002, PERMANOVA) and experimental temperature (P = 0.022, PERMANOVA) interacted significantly with migration time. Fig. 5 (b) shows the correlation between migration time and experimental temperature and the thermophysiological response of different migrant groups. The direction of the vector represents the greatest correlation between migration time or experimental temperature and the thermophysiological response. The length of the vector represents the strength of the correlation with the thermophysiological response. The contour marked the landscape of the migration time, which was calculated using a nonlinear generalized additional model with thin-plate spline interpolation. The correlation between the temperature and the thermophysiological reaction dominated that of time. Time had no effect on the thermophysiological response of the HSWW group, but had opposing effects on the HSCW and SC groups.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Selection of physiological adaptation parameters of migrants
ce:section.ce:para: In order to rank the physiological parameters that can distinguish migration elements (time and birthplace), we used an RF algorithm to regress migration elements with four physiological thermal responses (skin temperature, core temperature, heart rate, and mean arterial pressure) under different experimental temperatures. The output variables should represent the combination of migration origin, time, and experimental temperature and can balance the weight of the three. The average values of the standardized migration times, origins, and experimental temperatures were taken as the model's output variables. The R 2 of the model was 83.1%. The RF model provides an importance measure of each input variable, expressed as %IncMSE in Fig. 6 , representing the percentage increase in the mean square error (MSE) of the output variable. A high value of %IncMSE indicates that compared with other input variables with lower values, this input variable is very important for the change of the output variable. Fig. 6 shows the %IncMSE ranking of the four physiological parameters. The %IncMSE of skin temperature was higher than that of the other three, indicating that skin temperature constituted the central predictive parameter to distinguish the migrants; that is, skin temperature is a physiological marker representing the thermal adaptation of migrants.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Skin temperature: a physiological marker of migrants’ thermal adaptation
The trend of mean skin temperature (MST) with migration time
ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 7 shows the MST of the subjects. The box section of Fig. 7 shows the overall distribution of the MST of the different migrant groups. The upper and lower limits of MST quartiles of the SC group were higher than those in the other groups. The upper quartile of the MST in the HSWW group was higher than in the HSCW group. The main part of Fig. 7 shows the MST of different migration groups for different migration duration under each condition; the trend was fitted by GAMM (Equation (3)), where s() is fitted with smoothing functions and ti() represents interactions of covariates. The adjusted R 2 of the model was 87.9%. The MSE was 0.22.

There were significant interactions between migration groups, times, and temperature (P < 0.001; ANOVA). There was no significant gender difference (P > 0.05; ANOVA). The MST of the HSCW group showed an upward trend under warm conditions, and the MST in the second year was higher than that in the first year; in the cold condition, the trend was opposite, which expresses the symmetry phenomenon of thermal adaptation. The MST of the HSWW group was stable at 21–26 °C and slightly higher in the second year at 28–33 °C. In the SC group, the MST in the second year was lower than that in the first year under the more extreme temperature conditions (33 °C and 31 °C). In the cold temperature (18 °C and 21 °C), the skin temperature in the summer of the second year was higher than that in the first year, but the change in winter was not apparent. The lower part of Fig. 7 shows a significant difference between the migrants and the control group on an annual time scale. The asterisk indicates a significant difference between the migration and the Xi'an groups in the corresponding season (P < 0.05; Tukey); the color of the asterisk represents different temperatures. In the second year of migration, the number of asterisks between the migration and Xi'an groups decreased compared with the first year. It means that the difference between migrants and locals gradually became less obvious in two years. There was no significant difference between the HSCW and Xi'an groups in the spring and summer of the second year, which may indicate that the skin temperature of the migrants was gradually adapting to the new environment.
Equation 4 MST = α Birthplace i × Temperature k + s (Time j) + ti (Time j × Temperature k × Birthplace i) + ε

ce:section.ce:section-title: Difference of mean skin temperature in different time scales
ce:section.ce:para: Table 5 (a), (b), and (c) show significant intra - and inter-group differences in the MST of subjects divided by day, week, and month. The asterisk indicates a significant difference between groups in the row and column (P < 0.05; Tukey). Color corresponds to different temperature conditions.

Due to the limitation of admission time, migrants enter Xi'an in the early autumn, so the time scale of day and week is located in the autumn of the first year of migration. Table 5 (a) shows the significant differences of MST between time and migration groups within the first 15 days of migration. On the first day of migration, there was no significant difference between the migration groups. There were significant differences between the HSCW and SC groups at almost every temperature condition at subsequent time points. There was no significant difference between the first 15 days in the HSWW group. The significant difference between each time group of SC group was concentrated in the cold condition. With the increase of time, the HSCW group showed significant differences in more and more time groups; there were significant differences between the 15th-day group and other time groups in most cold and warm conditions. It indicates that the MST of the HSCW migrants can show a significant adaptation trend after 15 days of migration.

Table 5 (b) shows the significant differences of MST between time and migration groups within the first four weeks of migration. The average MST of each subject on 1, 4, and 7 days was taken as the MST of the subjects in the first week of migration. The average MST at 9, 12, and 15 days was regarded as the MST at the second week of migration. There were significant differences in the HSCW group at each time point. There was no significant difference in the first four weeks of migration in the HSWW group. There was no significant difference between the first week and the second week of migration in the SC group, but there was a significant difference between the third and fourth weeks and other groups. There was a significant difference in MST between the HSCW and SC groups with time in almost all cold and hot conditions. Significant differences between the HSWW and SC groups appeared in the cold conditions and 31 °C.

The average MST of each subject in 1d-4w was taken as the MST of the subjects in the first month of migration. On the time scale of the month (1m–22 m), the skin temperature differed significantly between each migration group and mainly in the time elapsed between different seasons. There was no significant difference between the time categories in MST of group SC after nine months of migration. The MST of the HSCW group has obvious seasonal adaptability in the first year of migration; the MST in the winter and spring of the second year is significantly different from the four seasons of the previous year in terms of warm conditions. It means the skin temperature sensitivity of HSCW migrants to warm environment is enhanced.

The MST within the different migration groups in each time category was regressed with the experimental temperature. The coefficients of the regression relationship can be regarded as the sensitivity of the MST to the change of thermal environment for the different migrant groups at different time categories. The larger the slope, the more sensitive the MST was to the changes in the thermal environment. Fig. 8 (a) shows the sensitivity of the MST with migration time. Overall, the sensitivity of the SC group was higher than that of the southern migration and the Xi'an groups; the HSCW group had the lowest sensitivity. However, the STS rate of the HSCW group increased significantly with the increase of migration time; compared with the first day of migration, the STS rate increased by 57.5% two years after migration. The STS of the HSWW group increased slightly with the increase of migration time; compared with the first day of migration, the STS rate increased by 11.9% two years after migration. Compared with the first day of migration, the STS rate of the SC group decreased by 12.5% two years after migration.

Fig. 8 (b) shows the relative difference of average STS between the migration and Xi'an groups. The relative difference of STS between the migration and Xi'an groups gradually approached 0 with increased migration time. It indicates that the STS of migrants completed adaptation changes after two years. Moreover, season had a significant effect on the relative difference of STS between migrants and locals. For the HSWW and SC groups, the largest and significant difference was observed in the autumn of the first year of migration. For the HSCW group, the largest difference was in the winter of the first year of migration. In the spring and summer of the first year, the average relative difference of STS between the southern and Xi'an groups was less than 15%. In comparison, the relative difference of STS between the SC group and the Xi'an group was reduced by nearly 60% compared with the initial. It means that the STS adaptation speed of southern migrants seemed lower than that of the northern migrants.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Heart rate, MAP, and core temperature
ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 9 (a) shows a linear trend of heart rate with migration time. There was a positive correlation between the heart rate and the air temperature, but it is difficult to distinguish the lines in Fig. 9 (a) at air temperatures in the range from 21 °C to 28 °C. It may be because air temperatures in the comfortable to warm ranges did not cause intense physiological regulation of the body core. The heart rate of the northern subjects was significantly higher than that of the southern subjects. There was no significant difference in the heart rate between the HSCW and the HSWW groups. Compared with the Xi'an group, the heart rate of the HSCW and SC groups showed a slight decrease in high air temperature (31 °C and 33 °C) and a downward trend with migration time. The heart rate of the HSWW group was almost independent of migration time. Fig. 9 (b) shows that the MAP decreased with the increase of air temperature. The difference could not be seen at air temperatures above 26 °C. There were significant differences in the MAP between the migrant groups and the control group for the entire migration period (P < 0.05; Tukey).

Fig. 9 (c) shows the core temperature of the migration and control groups over time. There were no significant interactions between migration time, origin, and experimental temperature (P = 0.68; ANOVA). The mean core temperature of the subjects varied in a narrow range of 35.4–37 °C and increased with air temperature. At the highest air temperature, there was no significant difference between the subjects. At air temperature of 31 °C, 24 °C, and 21 °C, the core temperature of the HSWW group was significantly higher than that of the SC group (P < 0.05; Tukey). Significant differences between the HSCW, HSWW, and Xi'an groups were only observed at air temperatures of 26 °C and 24 °C (P < 0.05; Tukey). At air temperature of 18 °C, the core temperature of the HSWW group was significantly lower than that of the HSCW group (P < 0.05; Tukey). There was no significant gender difference (P > 0.05; ANOVA) in the results of heart rate, MAP, and core temperature.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Trend of TSV with migration time
ce:section.ce:para:
Fig. 10 shows the subjects' thermal sensation over migration time. The box section of Fig. 10 shows the overall distribution of the thermal sensation in the different migration groups. The upper and lower quartiles of the thermal sensation in the SC group were higher than those in the other groups. The upper quartile of thermal sensation in the HSWW group was higher than that in the HSCW group. The central part of Fig. 10 shows the GAMM fitting of the migrants' TSV under each temperature condition. The GAMM for subjective responses is shown in Equation (4), where Y can be TSV or TCV, ƒ () is a fitted smooth interaction. The adjusted R 2 of the model was 91.5%, and MSE was 0.22. The TSV of each group increased with the increase of experimental temperature. There were significant interactions of migration groups with time and air temperature (P < 0.001; ANOVA). There was no significant gender difference (P > 0.05; ANOVA). The TSV of the HSCW group showed an upward trend under warm conditions. There was a linear, decreasing trend in the SC group under warm conditions and an increasing trend at 18 °C. The lower part of Fig. 10 shows a significant difference between the migrants and the control group on a year scale. There were significant differences between the three migration groups and the Xi'an group in the four seasons of the first year. In the second year, there is hardly any significant difference in the TSV at the extreme temperatures (18 °C and 33 °C). This may indicate that the adaptability of migrants' perception of extreme temperature is higher than that of relatively mild temperature.
Equation 5 Y = α Birthplace i + ƒ (Time j × Temperature k × Birthplace i) + ε

ce:section.ce:section-title: Difference of TSV in different time scales
ce:section.ce:para: We compared the TSV of subjects at different time scales, as shown in Table 6 . Table 6 (a) shows the significant differences of TSV between time and migration groups within the first 15 days of migration. Significant differences between the groups were concentrated in the warm condition. There was no significant difference in the HSCW group within 15 days. The significant difference between the HSWW and other migration groups occurred mainly under warm conditions.

The same analysis was performed with the MST ( Table 5). Table 6 (b) shows the significant differences of TSV between time and migration groups within the first four weeks of migration. The TSV of the SC group differed significantly between the first two weeks. In the HSWW group, there was a significant difference between four weeks; but it was opposite of the HSCW group.

On the time scale of the month (1m–22 m), the differences in TSV between migration groups were mainly concentrated in winter and spring of the first year and spring and summer of the second year. The TSV of the HSCW group in the second winter was significantly lower than that in the first winter at 21 °C. Compared with the first year of migration, the TSV of the HSWW group increased significantly in the winter of the second year of migration at 28 °C. It shows that after a long period of winter with heating exposure, the thermal adaptation of the southern migrants' weakened. Interestingly, in the summer of the second year, the TSV of the SC group was significantly higher than that in the summer of the first year at 21 °C. It means that the sensitivity of northern migrants to cold environments is weakened after hot exposure in summer. It may be because the thermal exposure in summer expanded the comfort threshold of SC migrants and their sensation of cold exposure became more tolerant.

The slope of the regression relationship can be regarded as the subjects' TS to the change of thermal environment. The larger the slope, the more sensitive the TSV is to the change of thermal environment. Fig. 11 shows the TS and its relative differences between the migrants and the Xi'an group, which are similar to those of STS ( Fig. 8). Overall, the HSCW group had an upward trend; compared with the first day of migration, the TS increased by 15.6% after two years of migration. The TS of the HSWW group kept a very slight fluctuation with the increase of migration time. The overall TS of the SC group had a downward trend; compared with the first day of migration, the TS decreased by 10.1% after two years of migration.

The relative difference of TS of the HSCW group, SC group, and Xi'an group approached 0 with increased migration time. The changing range of relative difference of TS between the SC and Xi'an groups is narrower than that of STS ( Fig. 8). The relative difference of TS between the HSWW and Xi'an groups fluctuated gently around - 10% during two-year migration. The relative difference of TS between the SC group and the Xi'an group gradually was about 0 after the first year's winter. It means that the TS of the SC group has been adapted to the level of local people in the first year of migration. The relative difference of TS between the HSCW and Xi'an groups reached 0 in the second year of migration. It indicates that the adaptation speed of the SC group in TS was faster than that of southern migrants.

ce:section.ce:section-title: The trend of TCV with migration time
ce:section.ce:para: Fig. 12 shows the thermal comfort of the subjects over migration time. The box section of Fig. 12 shows the overall distribution of thermal comfort votes for the different migration groups. There was no significant difference between the HSWW and SC groups. The upper and lower quartiles of the HSCW group were lower than those of the HSCW and SC groups, showing a significant difference (P < 0.001; Tukey), indicating that HSCW group achieved thermal comfort more easily than the other migration groups. The main part of Fig. 12 shows the GAMM fitting of the TCV of different migration groups. The adjusted R 2 of the model was 64.5%, and MSE was 0.24. There were significant differences in the interaction of migration groups with time and air temperature (P < 0.001; ANOVA). There was no significant gender difference (P > 0.05; ANOVA). The TCV of the HSWW group showed an obvious increasing trend under more extreme temperature conditions. Moreover, when air temperatures approached the most extreme values, the TCV increased faster with time. The degree of discomfort in the HSCW group in the second year was higher than that in warm conditions in the first year; for cold conditions, the trend obviously depends on season. Moreover, the HSCW group was more uncomfortable in the second winter than in the first winter but opposite in summer. It indicates that the thermal adaptation of migrants in their original residence gradually subsided due to a long-term relatively comfortable thermal exposure. The SC group became more and more comfortable with the migration time only under extreme hot thermal conditions.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Difference of TCV in different time scales
ce:section.ce:para: Table 7 shows significant differences in the TCV of subjects between different time and migration groups. There was no difference in the HSCW group under any condition within 15 days of migration as shown in Table 7 (a). Compared with the analysis of the TSV ( Table 6), there were fewer significant differences in TCV between the migrants. There was no obvious change in the thermal comfort of the migrants on a time scale of days. Table 7 (b) shows the significant differences of TCV between time and migration groups within the first four weeks of migration. The thermal comfort of the HSWW group in the first two weeks was significantly different from that of the last two under warm conditions. Thus, the adaptation of thermal perception in the HSWW group began to develop after the third week.

The TCV differed significantly between the first winter and the second winter in the HSCW group as shown in Table 7 (c). There were significant differences in winter, spring and summer between the first and second year in the TCV of the HSWW group. There was significant difference in transition seasons between the first year and the second year in the SC group. Overall, the development of adaptation of the different migrant groups seemed to differ between seasons.

Since the relationship between the TCV and the experimental temperature was a quadratic function, we divided the experimental temperature into two groups: cold working condition (18–26 °C) and warm working condition (26–33 °C) to regress on TCV. The slope of the regression relationship can be regarded as the TCS of subjects to cooler or warmer conditions. The greater the absolute value of the slope, the more sensitive TCV is to the change of thermal environment. Fig. 13 (a) and (c) show the TCS with the change of migration time under cold and warm conditions, respectively. Fig. 13 (b) and (d) show the relative difference of TCS between the migrants and the Xi'an group under cold and warm conditions. Under the cold condition, the relative difference of TCS between migrants and the Xi'an group is opposite to that in Fig. 13 (a). While under warm conditions, the relative difference of the TCS between migrants and the Xi'an group was consistent with the trend of Fig. 13 (c). The trend of the TCS of migrants was different from TS ( Fig. 11) and STS ( Fig. 8). The TCS trends of the three groups of migrants were similar. In the second year of migration, the TCS of the SC group still differed more than 15% as compared with the Xi'an group after two years of migration under cold conditions, while the relative differences of TCS between southern migrants and the Xi'an group were around 0. It shows that the TCS adaptation of the southern migrants was faster than that of the northern migrants under cold conditions. In addition, interestingly, the thermal comfort of the HSCW group was more sensitive than that of the Xi'an group under the warm working condition in the second summer and exceeded the TCS of the Xi'an group by nearly 20%. It means migrants will request a high thermal comfort environment when repeatedly experiencing the same long-term thermal exposure level.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Physiological adaptation guided by different thermal experience and exposure
ce:section.ce:para: Extensive studies have found that there are differences in the physiological characteristics of indigenous people in different places [ 21, 24, 26, 54–57]. Most findings point to phenotypic rather than genotypic differences [ 58–60]. We also found significant phenotypic differences between subjects with different thermal experiences. For example, in the early stage of migration, the skin temperature of the SC group was significantly higher than that of the HSCW and HSWW groups in warm conditions and significantly lower than that of the southern group in cold conditions. The skin temperature of the HSWW group was significantly lower and higher than the HSCW group under the coldest and hottest conditions. The ranking of the sensitivity of the skin temperature to ambient temperature was SC > HSWW > HSCW. Even without considering the migration time, the HSCW and SC groups were distinctively different. These phenotypic differences are often confirmed to be related to specific climates and lifestyles [ 58]. From the perspective of long-term thermal experience, although the SC area is extremely cold outside and lasts longer, people have more opportunities to keep warm in the continuously heated indoor environment. The long-term comfortable indoor thermal experience may weaken their ability to cope with extreme heat or cold exposure stress. The HSCW and HSWW groups were more used to indoor temperature fluctuations due to the lack of indoor heating and also experienced warmer thermal conditions for a longer time, making the thermal physiological performance of different degrees of thermal exposure better than the SC group. In addition, we also found that under multiple temperature conditions, the core temperature of the HSWW group was significantly higher than that of the SC group. Nguyen et al. also reported that higher body core temperature was observed in people living in warm areas [ 55, 56]. It may be due to the evolutionary increase in core temperature caused by the human body to help reduce sweat-related water loss during the long and extreme hot and humidity acclimatization process in the HSWW group. At the same time, we also observed that the fluctuations of physiological parameters in the HSWW group appeared to be relatively stable among the subjects. It may be because HSWW migrants gained better thermoregulation and cardiovascular functions than other groups in the long-term hot and humid environment [ 61]. In addition, we also observed that the heart rate and blood pressure of the northern subjects were significantly higher than those of the southern subjects. Some cardiovascular-related medical reports show that the prevalence of blood pressure and hypertension is positively correlated with geographic latitude [ 62, 63]. However, there are many causes of heart rate and blood pressure changes, which are related to geographical and climatic factors, economic factors, medical quality, and diet [ 64]. Therefore, it is difficult to say that the effect of thermal experience completely forms the difference in heart rate and blood pressure among migrants, and it still needs to be studied.

The difference between the thermal experience and the current environment exposure seems to drive the plasticity of migrants' thermal adaptation in different directions and strengths. As shown in Fig. 7, we found that the skin temperature of the HSCW group in warm conditions and cold conditions changed in opposite directions as the migration time increased. However, this phenomenon of “adaptation symmetric with temperature” was not observed in the other migration groups. It may be because the HSCW group experienced a relatively extreme temperature range for a longer time (average indoor temperature in winter: 13.6 °C, average indoor temperature in summer: 30.6 °C, based on the data in Fig. 1). When they moved to Xi'an, where there are heating facilities in winter and the average indoor temperature in summer is lower (difference of indoor exposure in winter: 6.2 °C, difference of indoor exposure in summer: 1.2 °C, based on the data in Fig. 1), they no longer experienced the same degree of cold and heat stress. Therefore, the physiological advantages accumulated by long-term thermal history degenerated. In contrast, the difference in indoor exposure levels in winter and summer between HSWW and Xi'an was - 1 °C and 0.6 °C, respectively; the winter indoor temperature exposure difference of the SC group was 1.8 °C. Both are much lower than the exposure difference between the HSCW group's original residence and the current residence. It also confirms that in natural domestication, the difference in the level of thermal exposure required to drive the development of migrants' physiological cold adaptation is greater than that required for heat adaptation. In addition, we have also found that differences in the level of thermal exposure have brought about differences in the development direction of thermal adaptability. As shown in Fig. 8 (a), the skin temperature sensitivity of the northern migrants decreased over time, while the southern group experienced the opposite. Northern migrants have become accustomed to a smaller temperature range in their original residence. Their current residence's broader thermal exposure level forces them to increase their ability to adapt to temperature changes. The situation of southern migrants is just the opposite. Their relatively comfortable current residence has weakened their physiological adaptability. However, we can observe that the migrants have reached the same level as the Xi'an group during the two-year migration in terms of skin temperature sensitivity. However, at some temperatures, the skin temperature of the migration group was significantly different from that of the Xi'an group in the second year, as shown in Fig. 7. It shows that the skin temperature sensitivity (slope), which represents the “thermal physiological adaptability,” can be fully adapted within two years of migration. However, the phenotypic differences caused by the thermal experience at the physiological level between the migrants and the local people still exist.

Notably, we observed significant differences and sensitivity changes in skin temperature from the early stage to the later migration stage. In this study, the skin sensible heat loss under different temperature stimulation was calculated according to Equation (6) [ 45]to evaluate the thermal regulation ability of migrants. Fig. 14 shows the sensible heat loss of migrants. The sensible heat loss difference of migrants was within the limit of 3 W/m 2 between two years. The sensible heat loss of HSCW group in the second year of migration at 18 °C was lower than that in the first year of migration, but opposite at 31 and 33 °C; The sensible heat loss of the HSWW group in the second year of migration was higher than that in the first year of migration in winter; The sensible heat loss of SC group at 31 and 33 °C in the first year of migration was higher than that in the second year of migration. For Southern migrants, the thermal experience in Xi'an was a thermal de-adaptation process. Under the thermal adaptation of long-term thermal experience in the original place, Southern migrants may have lower vasodilation and sweating threshold under heat exposure, and HSCW migrants may also have higher vasoconstriction and trembling threshold. The mild thermal environment in Xi'an may decrease Southern migrants' thermal regulation ability. For example, the delay of vasodilation and sweating function under heat exposure may increase skin temperature and sensible heat loss of Southern migrants. On the contrary, for SC migrants, the thermal environment of Xi'an provides a natural thermal adaptation process, and the thermal regulation ability of SC migrants increased, especially in heat exposure.

Interestingly, we found that the sensible heat loss of the SC group increased slightly at the cold temperature in summer. It may be due to cross adaptation between cold and heat [ 65]. The SC group developed heat adaptation and improved its tolerance to cold when repeatedly exposed to a hot environment in summer. It may be due to the slow vasoconstriction reaction, allowing more blood to flow to the periphery [ 66, 67], and manifested as the rise of skin temperature and a slight increase in sensible heat loss. Hessemer et al. also reported that thermal adaptation for five days at 55 °C of ambient air temperature reduced the shivering threshold [ 68]. The rise of sensible heat loss was an adverse condition of the SC group under cold exposure. We speculate that low-temperature stimulation is rare in the summer, and there is a lack of intense thermoregulation to form a complete cold acclimation. Moreover, small vasoconstriction changes and slightly warm skin temperature can save energy in the human core area and prevent cold stress. In addition, the experimental time of 40 min in this study may not be enough to form a steady-state stage, and it still needs a longer experimental time to determine the above mechanism.
Equation 6 Q ss=(t sk-t o) / (R cl + 1/ (f cl × h))
Where Q ss is the sensible heat loss (W/m 2), tsk is the skin temperature (K), to is the operative temperature (K), R cl is the thermal resistance of clothing, here is 0.06975 m 2 K/W, f cl is the clothing area factor, here is 1.1 and h is the sum of convective and radiative heat transfer coefficient (W/m 2·K).

However, the core temperature did not change significantly with migration time. This supports that in the long-term thermal adaptation of migrants, skin temperature plays a more important role in thermoregulation than core temperature. It also means that under the long-term adaptation of migrants, the core temperature set point in thermoregulation will not change. The cold and hot threshold of skin temperature will change with the change of migration time.

ce:section.ce:section-title: Thermal sensitivity of migrants: changeable Griffiths constant and comfort temperature
ce:section.ce:para: Humphreys et al. believe that the assumption that “all conditions are the same” implied in Griffiths constant's calculation can be interpreted as: (1) at the observation time, the subject's adaptive behavior does not change, and (2) all other factors remain unchanged except temperature [ 69]. Therefore, the thermal sensitivity in Fig. 11 (a) can be considered as the “Griffiths constant” of migrants under the steady uniform environment. The thermal sensitivity of the three groups of migrants ranged from 0.24 to 0.38/°C, close to the thermal sensitivity of 0.33/°C of sedentary people under a steady-state environment reported by Fanger [ 1], but lower than the universal Griffiths constant of 0.5/°C derived from field studies mainly in office buildings [ 70]. Rupp et al. claimed that the Griffiths constant is actually a variable; they estimated thermal sensitivity values of 0.44/°C for office buildings during air-conditioning operation and of 0.21/°C during natural ventilation [ 71]. Our study highlighted the importance of time in assessing the thermal sensitivity of migrants. We observed that the thermal sensitivity of migrants would evolve, and that the evolution process is related to the migration origin; the thermal sensitivity of HSCW migrants increased with the increase of migration time, while SC migrants were the opposite. This phenomenon may be attributed to the difference in thermal exposure levels between migrants' original and current residence.

The comfort temperature is obtained by Griffiths' method (Equation (7)) [ 72], as shown in Fig. 15 . The comfort temperature of migrants is related to the origin and time of migration. The comfort temperature of the HSCW, HSWW, and SC groups fluctuated in the range of 24.3–26.6, 25.2–26.6, and 25–26.8 °C, respectively. The comfort temperature of migrants showed seasonal adaptation in the first year of migration. In winter, the comfort temperature of SC migrants was higher than that of HSWW and HSCW migrants; the opposite was observed in summer. We also calculated the neutral temperature using linear regressions and found the result was consistent with the comfort temperature. It is worth noting that Ji et al. [ 29] reported that the preferred temperature of migrants who migrated from the northern hemisphere in winter to the southern hemisphere in summer would increase with the increase of migration time within four weeks of migration. It may be due to the large seasonal span of migration; migrants need to adjust their bodies to match the surrounding environment quickly. In addition, we observed that the comfort temperature of HSCW migrants in the second winter increased by 0.8 °C compared with the previous year. The comfort temperature of HSCW and HSWW migrants in the second summer decreased by 1.5 and 0.6 °C, respectively, compared with the average value of that in the first year. It means that when we design the indoor thermal environment for migrants, we cannot ignore migrants' dynamic thermal comfort experience. We recommend deriving thermal sensitivity and comfort temperatures according to the origin and time of migration rather than using general comfort standards to design thermal environments for migrants. This can provide thermal comfort for migrants and is conducive to the flexibility and energy-saving of building thermal environment design.
Equation 7 T comf = T + (0-TSV) /G
Where T comf is the comfort temperature (°C), T is the temperature (°C), and G represents the changeable Griffiths constant, which is the thermal sensitivity of migrants in Fig. 11 (a).

ce:section.ce:section-title: The rhythm of thermal adaptation development: a comparison between the physiological and psychological level
ce:section.ce:para: Thermal adaptation is mainly manifested by the interaction of physiological adaptation, psychological adaptation, and behavioral adaptation. In the above analysis and previous series of field investigations [ 35, 36], we discussed the characteristics of each adaptation layer with time and space. However, which level is leading the development of thermal adaptation? Does the level of dominant adaptation change with time scale, seasonal change, or space? To answer these questions, we needed to measure the gap between the adaptation layers. We chose skin temperature as the representative parameter of the physiological adaptation level; TSV and TCV are representative parameters of psychological adaptation. First, we normalized the three representative parameters to the range of 0–1; then, the Euclidean distance between each migration group and the control group under each time category and different adaptation levels was calculated, as shown in Fig. 16 . The difference in psychological adaptation between southern migrants and local people was larger than the physiological adaptation. In the winter, after two years of migration, the physiological level of the southern group still maintained a gap of more than 90% compared with the previous year, while the psychological level was reduced by about 50%. This reflects the strong response of the psychological adaptation to the seasonal changes of the migration environment and dominates the overall thermal adaptation development. The thermal adaptation rhythm of the SC group was different from that of the southern migrants at all levels. In the early stage of migration, the physiological level of the SC group was larger than that of the thermal sensation level, and the fluctuations of physiological and psychological levels were inconsistent. It reflects the change of thermal adaptation rhythm caused by the difference of short-term and long-term thermal history at different adaptation levels. It may be because the thermal adaptation has entered the rhythm of seasonal cold adaptation before migration. In the early stage of migration, the response intensity of physiological adaptation level to the changes of thermal environment was lower than that of psychological level, so the difference of physiological adaptation between SC group and Xi'an group was greater than that of psychological adaptation. In addition, the SC and Xi'an groups had a long-term heating history in winter, but they have not experienced a high-temperature environment in summer. So the peak of adaptation difference of southern migrants appears in winter, while that of the SC group appears in summer. In summer, after two years of migration, the gap of physiological adaptation level between the SC and Xi'an groups was about 60% lower as compared with the previous year, while the gap of the psychological adaptation level remained more than 80%. It may be due to the SC group's psychological “emotional inertia” [ 73] after being accustomed to the comfortable thermal environment in their original place of residence. It may also indicate that the psychological adaptation was more difficult when transitioning from comfort to uncomfortable conditions than vice versa.

During two years, this study tracked the dynamic characteristics of the thermal adaptation of internal migrants moving from Hot Summer and Cold Winter (HSCW), Hot Summer and Warm Winter (HSWW) and Severe Cold (SC) areas to a cold region in China. The main conclusions are as follows.
(1)
The difference in thermal exposure between migrants' original and current residence needed to drive the development of cold adaptation was greater than that of heat adaptation. However, the phenotypic differences between the migrants and local people caused by long-term thermal experience still exist and are difficult to eliminate. We also found that skin temperature is a representative parameter of thermal physiological adaptation of migrants.
(2)
The thermal sensitivity and comfortable temperature of migrants are variables and related to the origin and time of migration. The comfortable temperature of the HSCW, HSWW, and SC groups fluctuated in the range of 24.3–26.6, 25.2–26.6, and 25–26.8 °C during a two-year period.
(3)
The psychological adaptation dominated the thermal adaptation development in the southern migrants who are not used to indoor heating, while the physiological adaptation dominated the thermal adaptation in the northern migrants who are used to indoor heating. In the winter, after two years of migration, the difference in psychological adaptation between the southern and the control groups was reduced by about 50%, compared with the previous year; however, the physiological adaptation was still more than 90% lower than that of the previous year. In the summer after two years of migration, the gap of the physiological adaptation between the SC group and the control group decreased by about 60% compared with the previous year, while the gap of psychological adaptation remained more than 80%. It may indicate that psychological adaptation is more difficult when transitioning from comfort to uncomfortable conditions than vice versa.
